item.description:
I am a first-year Computer Science PhD Student at Stanford University, co-advised by Leonidas Guibas and Gordon Wetzstein. My research lies in the intersection of computer graphics, geometry, and deep learning. Recently, I have been exploring 3D neural representations for large-scale scene reconstruction, 3D-aware GANs, and scene generation and editing. My work is graciously supported by a David Cheriton Stanford Graduate Fellowship.

Over the summer, I am interning at Adobe Research, London, working with Paul Guerrero and Niloy Mitra.

Previously, I worked at Google as a software engineer on mobile computational photography (mostly related to Portrait Mode on Pixel phones).

I was also a Computer Science undergraduate and graduate student at Carnegie Mellon University, advised by Keenan Crane. This culminated in my Master’s Thesis on quad meshing.

Outside of work, I enjoy cooking, working out, video/boardgames, and music (long-time swiftie). Also a fan of traveling and sports – go Ravens!.
